Hey all,

I find myself in a weird position and I'm wondering if anyone can relate or can offer insight to help clear up my confusion.  

In essence, I've been into MBTI almost a decade now, since high school, but due to a rough couple years after graduating college and living independently, I've come to question a lot of things about myself.  

I've most often gotten ENFJ as my test results, which I strongly identified with, though I got many others that also I identified with, including ISTP, and I more or less embraced the fluidity.  Now I know ENFJ's supposedly have a hard time seeing themselves objectively and have the same functions as ISTP's just reversed in the stack, which indicates ENFJ to me, but they're also rarely type 8 on the enneagram which makes me skeptical.  I started learning about the enneagram about two years ago and I'm all but certain I'm type 8w9, with the only real other consideration being type 9w8; they supposedly imagine themselves being more 8.  And statistically speaking, types 8 and 9 are far more strongly correlated to ISTP with ISTP also being far more common than ENFJ.  I'm not comfortable claiming to be some rare type.

Anyway, I won't go into detail here about "my deal". I've made another post on PerC that I edited down because it pages long, literally filled journals, talked (big step for me) to friends, family, a therapist, and done so much soul-searching stuff that I've found myself obsessive, obnoxious, and obviously still very confused about who I am.  Suffice it say, I'm at least good at compartmentalizing, adapting, work, and being self-sufficient.

But what is healthy for me?  Emotionally/mentally, I'm not entirely sure what my strengths and weaknesses are, so it's tough to narrow things down and figure it out.  I'm sensitive to other people but honestly pretty callous and have good intution, Se, and Ti. It's like I've a very broad, general, kind of vague identity, that's also well-balanced between ENFJ and ISTP.  I'm probably just very average, but that's why it's weird to read all this stuff for ENFJ 2's or ISTP 5's.  I connect with some things but not much.  I feel like a jack of all trades, master of none.

Anyone else an ENFJ 8?  Got any insights?  Am I just overthinking all of this? I'll post in the ISTP forum too eventually, but the vibe seems much more subdued and like I wouldn't get the same kind of feedback.

Cheers!

column2: Is that relatable to anyone here?
column3:
Well, I have long-standing fondness for intj girls.
I am attracted to their cool, badass exterior which hides a potential for deep passion that is just hinted and that I'm eager to bring out. Making an intj express hints of emotion is very endearing, more so if it's towards you.

Hi! I just have some questions, as I'm trying to clarify my type...I know most people may just skip past all these questions, but even answering a few helps! Thank you!

1. Are you a type 2 Enneagram? If so, are you a 2w3?

2. What tritype are you?

3. What is your socionics type? What are your primary and secondary romance styles according to the socionics test?

4. According to a cognitive functions test, put your 8 functions in order from greatest to least

5. What is your attitudinal psyche type?

6. What is your temperament (the two highest are your temperament)?

7. What is your 5x5 alignment test results?

8. Can you tell when someone is being fake to get something out of you? For example: I was at the archery range shooting my bow when I ended up talking to a stranger there. We were talking and he asked me if I had ever been hunting. Said no, I had no idea how...he started using my first name a lot and began saying how he'd totally teach me if I had a place for us to hunt. Now, I'm no idiot. I knew very clearly that he didn't give a shit about teaching me to hunt, he just wanted a place to hunt and probably had no real interest in teaching me. I took his number out of politeness and told him I'd text him if I found somewhere. I had no intention of ever texting him. When people start saying my first name a lot (when it's clear they're talking to me and they're total strangers to me), any trust I had for them instantly goes out the window...it's something pulled straight out of the car salesman handbook and is an instant sign, at least in my eyes, that they're not being genuine. If it's someone I know, that's a lot different.

9. Do you ever have a thought cross your mind regarding a subject, agree with it, then 2 seconds later, realize how immoral it is and realize you don't agree with it? This could be regarding the death penalty, punishments for abhorrent crimes, etc. For example: You hear something about a rapist and think to yourself "We should kill all rapists"...then a second later realize "Hey...that's not okay at all, they deserve the right to a fair trial like everyone else."

10. What other types have you tested as?

11. How turbulent are you?

12. Do you ever give unsolicited advice regarding everyday things to people...I.E if you're bowling and you see something a friend could improve, you tell them.

13. Do you give unsolicited life and emotional advice to close friends when they're going through a tough time?

14. Are you the type of person to tell someone going through a rough time that "Things will be better one day soon." and give them hope for the future?

15. Do you tell people you love that you love them at least once a day, sometimes more than once a day?

16. Do you ever get so overcome with feelings of affection and emotions while talking to your partner, that you simply say their name and then tell them how much you love them...even if it's totally out of the blue.

17. Do people often ask you, dumbfounded, how you jumped from one topic you were talking about to another one that is completely unrelated

18. Have you ever been told you have no common sense? Ever been told you have so much potential? 

19. Are you always early or on time to obligations?

20. Do you like making large groups of people (40+) laugh?

21. Ever considered doing standup comedy

22. Is the feeling of social rejection very hard, if not the hardest thing  for you to handle?

23. Do you take way more awful shit from people than you should?

24. Do you think there is ever a situation where you could beat the shit out of someone? Whether it be protecting your children, your spouse, your best friend, a loved one?

25. Were you the "weird kid" when you were younger?

26. Do you have ADHD?

27. How quickly does your mood change everyday

28. On a scale of 1-10, how much do you wish you could dance good/play an instrument/sing?

column2: I finally met an ENFJ male! cant stop thinking now...insights appreciated!
column3:
Hi everyone 

This amazing ENFJ is the facilitator of a personal development type class I'm taking. (MBTI is part of the class so I actually got confirmation he is an ENFJ!) I hardly know the guy of course, but intuitively I just felt like...it's so hard to put into words even! The first time our eyes met...I was left wondering what the frilly heck just happened?! This was before he even spoke! Not in a romantic starry eyed way, but I just felt some kind of connection in a way I have not experienced before. (Ive had plenty of crushes and relationships)

 It even seems at times we can communicate so much to each other through our eyes (while he is talking at the front to the group)...it almost feels weirdly telepathic at times. (one time he said something like "don't forget people can't read your mind"...but then he paused and said in a quieter tone '"or who knows, maybe they can ha" and kind of half glanced in my direction with a shy smile (maybe I imagined it being directed at me...but it seemed sort of out context to add that in otherwise )

So it has been just over a week since the class started...he really has this way of drawing me out and making me feel less self-conscious. I am even spontaneously laughing any time I find something funny and am one of the most talkative in the group even though I'm usually silent unless directly asked a question. This is so weird for me. I like this new version, but it's weird haha It's so great being around him! 

And even though I'm happily single right now (not looking in the least)....I found myself secretly wishing and hoping that he is single so there might be an opportunity to get to know him better once the class is over (in 4 weeks) and see what happens because so far we seem to be so naturally in-tune and "get" each other...I think the ENFJ-INFP do seem to compliment each other so well...now I know what I've been missing out on all this time! 

Problem is...he's not single. 

He mentioned his girlfriend very casually a few times during anecdotes or whatever (they live together and have a dog is all I know)

BUT before I say anything else, I want to be clear that  I'm not looking for advice on how to steal him from his girlfriend or how to get him to like me. If someone is taken, they are off-limits in my mind and I've always been able to just accept that we aren't meant to be obviously and let it go. Well...except this time? Please don't judge...but I'm sort of now secretly hoping that maybe his girlfriend and him have been having problems for a long time and are on the verge of breaking it off. I can't help it. 

Here's the thing...I've been reading about ENFJ and how they are friendly and attentive to everyone naturally which can come across as romantic interest even when not intended. So I was fine with that, thinking that's probably all that's going on here...but there are just a few examples that leave me wondering...and I'd feel better if you can give your best guess on if you feel this could be feelings developing on his part or just him being exceptionally good at what he does (making people feel good about themselves) and I'm looking a little too hard for comfirmation...lol

-When he is talking in front of the group, I noticed that he is looking at me a lot of the time ( he looks around the room but then his eyes seem to come back to me anytime he pauses) and we often lock eyes and exchange smiles (could be just that I am so smiley and receptive when it comes to him? lol I dunno
-When he is not up front teaching and we are near each other he becomes a lot more shy, he'll smile at me but it's more of a goofy grin and he can't seem to make direct eye contact while talking and seems to fumble over his words but is not that way with the others in the group. One time he was standing around talking to a couple others in the group so I walked over to join in the conversation and he got really quiet
-when he is sitting next to me during group activities, I "feel"something...I dunno what...he doesn't talk to me, but I feel some vibe from him that he is interested. Maybe it's all in my head gah. 
-he seems to be tailoring his personal examples around things he knows interest me. Ie)the day after he found out I have kids and mentioned running late for art class, he mentioned on the weekend how he talked to his 7 year old nephew on the phone and was going on about their conversation and then later mentioned he had been to see his friend's art exhibit over the weekend as well. (this is just 1 example of how he seems to do this because and I don't notice him doing it with others)
-see him looking at me often through my peripheral vision when we're working independently (I think but I am so prone to blushing, I'm too afraid to try to catch him to confirm lol) But maybe this doesn't mean anything either? maybe he's just observing me?


Sorry for the ramble...I guess what I really want to know is do you think this could be interest and if it is do you think that means he feels the way I do which means his relationship must be going badly because he seems like the type that would be fiercly loyal? This is ideal scenario for me and I'm plenty patient...I am not saying I want to date him anytime soon...just that the potential is there. But if he is in a happy relationship and/or is not interested I want to be able to just let this go. And I think I can once I know. 

Is there something I can say or do that is appropriate in this scenario (classroom) to get clearer confirmation one way or the other so I can stop this thinking and analyzing everything?

I'll keep this simple.

For over two months I've been dating a woman who tested as an ENFJ. I believe she *may* be ESFJ, I'm having trouble drawing deep, intuitive, topics out of her. Being honest, I won't be able to fall in love without that and I'll have to end the relationship if this is the case. But we get along great and I want to give this the best shot I can.

As an ENFJ, how would you like questions phrased to bring out deeper, more intuitive, discussions?

I know its pretty much discussed to death - everytype could thereotically every type yada yada.
But how likely do you think it is to be a 1w9 ENFJ? I cant say with certainty I'm a ENFJ, being an INFJ is definately another option. But I gravitate more towards ENFJ, cuz I relate more to being Ti-last and Fe-first than Ni-first and Se-last and I KNOW by now Imma NFJ and I'm 90% sure I'm w9 and not w2. 
So how possible do you think it is for an ENFJ to actually be 1w9 and not actually be a mistyped INFJ?

column2: The Anxiety Handshake... is he nervous?
column3:
There is this guy that we both had a liking towards each other about 5 years ago, things went downhill because he was not ready for commitment and other complications - however I have always been in love with him.

I saw him with a bunch of friends at a bar last week and being the tipsy confident me I went up to him and said hello. I went too shake hands with him and he was so nervous I think because he shook my hand very soft and gently. He said he did not recognise me but looked really glad to see me and said that he remembers me back 5 years ago, we continued to chat, he cracked some humour here and there (also laughed at my jokes too). I also noticed he spoke quite deep and loudly, smiled a lot, his eyes were lit up/all big and was looking directly at my face when I was talking to him. 

After about 5 mins we had to part ways and when I said goodbye I put out my hand to shake hands; he grabbed my hand and he shook very soft and gentle. Then I texted him straight afterwards and told him that it was nice to see him and to have a nice evening; he messaged me back saying "Nice to see you too" (he's always been a robotic text messager, dry and straight to the point mind you). 

Do you reckon he would still possibly be interested - I want to ask him if he wants to catch up for drinks some time in the future.

column2: What have your interactions been like with INFPs?
column3:
Hey ENFJs, hi, hello, hope you don't mind me scootin' into your turf.

The reason I ask is because AFAIK I've only ever properly interacted with one ENFJ and I clicked with that person on a level I've never experienced with anyone else in my life, just immediately I opened up to them with all my thoughts and all my feels and they did the same with me, and I don't think I've ever had that kind of relationship with anyone before, I'm usually really reserved and private. They seemed to lean on me in particular as a kind of moral support for the short while I knew them and that was like whoah. Affection is nice.

I've done some thinking on the whole thing and while I'm not a fan of saying X type is/isn't compatible with Y type because it varies from person to person, I think there is good reason to suggest that INFPs and ENFJs are very compatible as people, mostly because of that INFP desire to be understood combined with that ENFJ desire to better understand others, and I'm wondering if I'm right about that from the ENFJ perspective, and if you've had that same kind of dynamic with INFPs in the past.

Do you guys have any specific examples of INFPs you've met in your life and how your interactions have been with them, to support/refute this idea? If I'm wrong and there's no pattern that's totally okay, I think you guys are great regardless. And of course it'll still vary from person to person, but I'm curious as to whether there's a pattern.

column2: Tale of epic ENFJ romance gone wrong
column3:
Hello! I?ôm an ENF(T)P. I was in a relationship with an ENFJ, and I?ôm writing for therapeutic purposes and perhaps to mine some wisdom from NFs. My story begins with an encounter with a beautiful girl with a huge heart and a lot to offer. We loved each other deeply and were wrapped up into each other like a magical cocoon of energetic bliss. I could share some of the crazy gushed out poetry and love notes we shared with each other, but I?ôll spare you. 

We moved in together and things went terribly wrong within a week. The week prior to the move in we were still in love with no sign of pending troubles. The situation is unbelievably complex in some ways and unbelievably simple in others. It?ôs my tendency to assume the entirety of the blame for the failure of my relationships, but I?ôm coming to realize that we created that relationship together and the blame is shared. 

The simple explanation of what went wrong is that when relationships become more committed, the fire burns more dimly. I felt I could relax, became more boyish, and became complacent in truly connecting with her. This, I?ôm coming to realize was an unconscious test to see if she loved my inner child, but it?ôs no doubt a form of immaturity that needs to be weeded out like cancer. Because no one loves a man who hasn?ôt tamed the inner child, nor should they. No need to elaborate on her faults and shortcomings, since they were outside my domain of control. However, It?ôs worth saying that it?ôs the idea/symbol of numinous perfection at the basis of our cognitive structures that plagued both of us. No human is perfect and if you believe they are deep down, then this inner belief prevents true human love. I believe we both overestimated each other in this way. 

The more complicated explanation is that she felt homesick. She was away from her family, familiar territory, ecosystem of friends, and I became her entire ecosystem. I had friends to introduce her to and she had a job lined up but a week wasn?ôt enough time to make the transition.  This created anxiety in her when we had the smallest of disagreements. The new ecosystem, me, couldn?ôt provide her the same feelings of safety, comfort and masculine love couldn?ôt compete with her home life, characterized by a lush abundance of people and places to go. 

Because this made me exceedingly anxious, I became afraid that she would leave and became anxious myself. I became self absorbed and distant to her emotions, because I interpreted her anger and frustration as a lack of desire to be with me. I gave up on trying anything because I didn?ôt want to her to have any friction if she decided to leave. I told her it was fine she needed to be home, because she?ôs only 21 and needed more adventures. I was proud of myself for handling it this way, until the final moments before she left (I?ôll get to this later). 

She wanted to stay in a long distance relationship. I declined because, at the time, I was interpreting her wanting to leave as a rejection of me rather than a rejection of the situation. Obviously, it?ôs a mix of the two but I believe it?ôs mostly the second one. Anyway, on our final day together, she wanted to cuddle for our last hours, and so we wound up in the bedroom. I emotionally was dead inside but held her nonetheless whilst cracking jokes to ease the tension. I stared at the ceiling, and she asked me what I was thinking. I told her, ?újust thinking about what I?ôm gonna do this weekend?? to avoid actually answering the question. 10 mins later she inquired what I was doing this weekend. I ashamedly replied that I was going to get laid, and this hurt her deeply, and she then stormed out. She reached out a few times, and I reached out a few times. The last time I spoke with her, she terribly angry. 

To be honest, I miss her and want her back. Other women have been disappointments in comparison to her.  But I honestly don?ôt want her back now. I?ôd like to wait until I?ôve had enough time to work on myself. Also, I?ôd like to wait until she?ôs at least out of college in a year before I would pursue her again.

However, whether I decide to get her back or not in the future, I?ôd like to see her blossom in life and meet her goals of becoming. Maybe even encourage her once in a while, even if it?ôs once in a long while. She?ôs deleted me on social media however. The relationship has been over for about 2 months. And she is still angry with me. I?ôve reached out to apologize once, and she?ôs still angry. My question is: wtf should I do to not be completely disconnected with someone I shared deep love with?
I am told by some that ENFJ's and INFP's are the perfect romantic match. What do you think?

I guess when you read the descriptions, they make ENFJs come across as very chameleon like. I try to be very much a chameleon, but sometimes my eccentricity leaks out. So...can ENFJs be eccentric? Or does strangeness suggest another type entirely?

Hello guys and gals, it took me a while to get interested in ENFJs for some reason.. but I seem to et along with them mostly in a work environment. I'd like to know if any of you has created a meaningful friendship/relationship with an ENFP, and if so, what has led to it being successful, and if it fails every time, why do you think that is?

column2: Things to consider when considering an ENFJ/INFP relationship
column3:
I've been seeing a lot of threads about ENFJs and INFPs, and I'm not here to discourage it. I can totally relate the FJ attraction to FP, but I thought I'd present some thoughts to consider when considering such a relationship, potential pitfalls, and stuff considering that the two types are all 4 function opposite, so they see things similar but, kinda invertedly. I'm basing my observations, on my own experience with dating and befriending Fi types, and my limited knowledge of cognitive function theory, so please feel free to fill in what I might be leaving out or to correct my understanding if what I say is not completely accurate...

First of all, to the INFPs, something to consider about ENFJs, is that ENFJs tend to disclose, or at least look like they're disclosing a lot about themselves to a lot of people. Sometimes, they can give off the impression that you're especially special to them, and that they've confided to you something really deep and personal, but realize, as extroverted feeling types, for ENFJs, their feelings are not going to be as deep and personal as with Fi doms. ENFJs tend to approach and view people, more as groups. Not that they're blind to the individuality of each individual, but there's more awareness of the group and the group dynamic. 

Like, for instance, an ENFJ walks into a room with a group of people, and they see their best friend in the group, and they wanted to tell their friend something, but it's not particularly private. The ENFJ will probably approach the best friend, but also engage other members of that group so they won't feel left out. This may not be the case with every single ENFJ, but I've seen a lot with Fe doms, how many of them are more adept at engaging people as groups; I also find Fe's tend to often focus more on the behaviors and the dynamic of what goes on between people, than on the individuals involved. ENFJs can also be very chameleon-like, and can often adapt their behavior to be pleasing to people. Just remember feelings are extroverted so with ENFJs, they want them to be shared, they want a community. If you're friends with an ENFJ and they say something like "I feel like I don't have any friends" don't take it personally, because what they really mean might be more along the lines of "I don't feel like I have a cohesive group of friends," ENFJs may have certain individual friends but still, sometimes might feel a need for a group that creates a sense of family or community, especially if, for some reason, they're detached from their own families. (Okay so, did I get any of this right, ENFJs? lol)

So, regarding INFPs. In my experience with Fi-doms, they tend to see and approach people more as individuals; if an INFP walks into a room with a group of people, and they see their best friend, and they have something they want to tell them, they might either draw the best friend away from the group or wait til the conversation is over, because they tend to feel more comfortable with one on one interactions with people than group interactions. Not that, INFPs don't do well in groups. I find when it comes to group interactions, some INFPs can be very charming. It depends on the person, but from what I've seen, they tend to feel more comfortable interacting with one person at a time, so if you see an INFP interacting with someone, deep in conversation, and it seems like they're ignoring you, they might not mean to, maybe they just feel more comfortable conversing with one person at a time.  Another thing I've experienced with Fi's is that they don't have as strong a need for a cohesive group, but have a strong need to feel loved, appreciated, and accepted for who they are. 

Here's one of the biggest sources of snags based on what I've seen of ENFJs and INFPs that I've known:
In my experience, ENFJs can be very assertive and confrontational, especially when it comes to needs in a relationship. They tend to like to have issues talked out and done with. I kinda think it's that Fe being the flipside of Ti, which I associate with a sort of "troubleshooter mentality". Fe doms like to improve things and situations. Things may not necessarily be bad in their eyes, but they're always looking toward "How can we work together to make it better"
Whereas, in my experience, INFPs do not like to talk about things like that. They tend to be pretty laid back, and when something bothers an Fi-dom, often they just take it in, and not really address it, until they can't take it anymore. They tend to want to look for the positive in others, and be accepting of their flaws even if those flaws get on their nerves, so when an ENFJ addresses an issue, and INFP might take it personally, and feel like the ENFJ is not accepting them the way they're accepting the ENFJ.

Because of this, an ENFJ can easily be the more dominant partner. Like, I said above, INFPs can be pretty laid back. If something that they hold personal is attacked, then they might get visibly upset, otherwise, they basically let people be. I find, so far, that Fi types can be extremely vulnerable toward being used, manipulated, or talked into doing things they don't really want to do. ENFJs, on the other hand, well, the ones I've known at least, tend to have a way of taking the lead without realizing it sometimes, and while most ENFJs are not manipulative, it can lead to a situation in which the ENFJ can get their way wayyy more than the INFP, simply because they are more assertive with their needs.

The most important thing is to understand each other. Personally, even though I'm not an ENFJ, as far as I know, as an FJ, I could see myself with an FP despite our inherited differences, so based on what I've learned, the best thing is to, primarily understand the person as an individual. We are not completely defined by our functions, but each person is unique. Secondarily, it wouldn't hurt for an ENFJ to learn as much as they possibly could about Fi, and for the INFP to learn as much as they possibly can about Fe, and to realize that one is not necessarily better than the other, and how the other person thinks is not necessarily "wrong" just because it was different from yours.

I hope this is at least a little helpful, and, sorry if I said anything that is different from your experience, I'm just going by what I know so far....
If a lot of people loved each other, the world would be a better place to live... o hi Mark.

column2: Young ENFJ having a identity crisis
column3:
Hi all,

I'm Eddy, a 26-year-old Dutch male, with a long story. I hope my English is ok.

I just recently discovered that I?ôm an ENFJ. I'm not just an ENFJ, but an extreme one: I score 80+ % on extraversion, intuition and feeling, and 60% on judging.

I feel so disconnected from other people, I've always been shy and I?ôve lived an introverted life. I know I'm a real late bloomer, which is very annoying. I've never been in a romantic relationship, and I feel very ashamed of this. This is just not normal, especially for an extreme extravert like me. I just want to have a girlfriend, I want to feel 'normal'. I've read all these wonderful stories about ENFJ's on personalitycafe.com and other forums, which give me a lot of hope. I also relate to a lot of problems other ENFJ's describe on this and other forums.

I have been visiting a counselor for about four months now, and he diagnosed me with having a severe identity crisis. According to him, I've never been through puberty mentally. He said that I'm an extreme shy extravert, and that I have an ENFJ personality. I took some test myself, and I?ôve read personality descriptions, and I concur: I'm an ENFJ for sure, but an unhappy/unhealthy one. I never thought that I am/was an extravert though.

I just can't wrap my head around the fact that I haven't found a girl. I'm not talking about 'the one', but just A girl. I've seen guys much more shy, more ugly, less intelligent than I am, and have had some success relationship-wise. These guys obviously got self-confidence because of the fact that they were able to get women.

I've had a lot of friends for the past ten years. I've helped them with a lot of things, even giving them dating and relationship advice, which is quite remarkable considering the fact that I?ôve no experience in that department what so ever. Why are they not friends with me anymore? Well, they pretty much dumped me, because they are in romantic relationships, and they don't need me anymore, or I just don't fit in there evolved lives. It boggles my mind.

I've two bachelor degrees, and I'm just a thesis away from obtaining my master?ôs degree. Now I even doubt if this is the right carrier for me. I doubt about everything right now. I'm 26 years old, and I haven't reached one milestone of life. No girlfriend (now, or at least had one in the past), no carrier (to peruse), no social life, no nothing. Hell, i don't even feel like I'm 26 years old already; a 16-year-old boy must be more mature that I am.

I've a lot of older, mostly retired acquaintances. They were very successful men and women in their time. I'm talking about business people, doctors, and artists. I love to talk to them, telling about my problems. They cannot wrap their heads around it either. I've been told by them that I?ôm the smartest, charismatic and promising man they've ever met; especially this young in age. This sounds great of course, but it makes me doubt even more. What's wrong with me? What (simple thing) have I overlooked, or missed?

I have a female cousin from Canada. Her parents are Dutch, and immigrated to Canada 30 years ago. She moved to Holland two years ago, she's now 28. She is the most beautiful girl I?ôve ever seen (I know, she family, so that's saying something!). She has a Canadian bachelor and master degree in neuropsychology, and is -also- a thesis away from obtaining a Dutch master?ôs degree in neuropsychology. She's also in doubt if this is her 'thing'. She's been single for her entire life as well. She looks very confident, but it took me just seconds to let my ENFJ-charm open her up: she cried about the fact that her two much younger sisters and her older brother were (getting) married. She also feels like she hasn?ôt reached a single milestone of life. She has various degrees, she is very beautiful and she immigrated on her one, so that?ôs not nothing. I always have great advice for people, but not this time. I don't understand the problem, let alone having a solution for it. I have the same problem, and I don't get it either. I think she's an ENFJ as well.

To me, it looks like having an ENFJ personality is a curse. It just doesn't work for me, and it doesn't bring me anything in life (as well as for my cousin). Great if it works for you, and I enjoy reading your stories, but it depresses me too.

I hope you can help me. Is this an ENFJ thing, or is it just me?

Hello everyone, 

Yesterday I posted a request for feedback from members of the ENFJ Forum about profiles that have been developed for this Type. I am very grateful for the responses I received. I made a similar request to the other 15 Forum members as well and intend to do the same with this posting. 

I recently published the ENFJ profile that I have developed over the years and am hoping that I can publish the next version of this profile with the direct help of ENFJs themselves. While I have attempted to put this profile together in the language of ENFJs, I must admit that this is not my own MBTI type and, therefore, I am quite sure that I have not met the mark. 

Here?ôs what I am looking for specifically. I would like to identify two individuals to help me. The first would be a layperson who has validated that they are indeed a very strongly identifiable ENFJ who is willing to read the profile in depth and to suggest ways that it can be edited to reflect the true language of the ENFJ. The second individual would be an ENFJ counseling professional who would look at the profile from a clinical perspective. This is the perspective that led me to the MBTI in the first place. I am convinced that clinicians must be aware of the subtle way that each of the MBTI types can best achieve the highest level of mental health for themselves. I have little to offer these two individuals at this point, except formal written credit for the valuable input that they will provide, as well as access to all sixteen of the profiles I just published. Depending upon how successful the publication of these profiles goes, I hope to also offer monetary compensation as well at some point. I know this isn?ôt much to go on, but I am hoping that there are at least a few folks in this discussion group who are still reading this request and who would like to contribute to our collective understanding of the ENFJ. 

If it would help to look at some of my work, you can access my website at https://www.mythinkingstyle.com/ 

If you are interested in either of these positions on behalf of other ENFJs, please email me at mythinkingstyle@yahoo.com

Thank you for your consideration,

Nathan, ENTJ
Nathan Church, M.S., Ph.D.

column2: Do you experience Ni this way?
column3: If I am an ENFJ actually then this might be my use of Ni. I daydream a lot of different people's behaviour in certain moments(facial expression, tone of voice, comebacks, mischief). There are snatches of social response that I either liked very much, strongly disliked, try to use in the future, or attach a certain meaning to(this person did this because they want to obtain a certain effect, they did this because they want to fit in). But I don't dwell on an image, I move from one to another as in a movie, and they keep repeating themselves. i think it's all obsessive because Ni can't settle for a conclusion until it has enough data.

column2: what to do about this confusing enfj. (super guarded and not an open person)
column3:
I've dated an Enfj once before and its the same thing. Very guarded and hard to get to know. Is this usually the case with Enfjs?

Anyway, i'm in the early getting to know you phase with this new Enfj and ive run into the same roadblocks. Like i know he is interested because he messages me everyday, when he says "im going out now but ill message you when i get home" he always does. Butttt I'm the one constantly having to lead the conversation and think about what to talk about. 

I try to bring up funny stories and i get a "haha lol" then he goes silent and doesn't know what to say. I ask him a ton of questions to get to know him better which he seems to like but most of his responses are quite shallow in the sense that he never opens up to have deeper conversation. I even tried to start by opening up first and talking about my insecurities but his response has been pretty lacking when it comes to that too! I just cant figure him out and its doing my head in. He doesn't seem to like it either when I bring up heavier topics too. 

Am thinking perhaps I should perhaps do one of the following:

a) play hard to get (though I am not sure if this works well on ENFJs or if it will even work on him because he seems to have some experience with girls ignoring or dropping him and losing interest once the conversation dies down)

b) tell him he is frustrating the crap outta me and why (but I don't know if this will change anything. I just worry he will think this is too much drama and shut off completely. Also im not sure but arent ENFJs very bad at handling conflict/confrontation?

Any advice Enfjs reading this?

I feel like I'm a dark ENFJ. Basically still a decent person, but a little rough around the edges. I don't need deep relationships with most people though I might probe them to see what makes them tick and offer suggestions. Helping people but there's always a comfortable gap there so I don't get too involved, if you know what I mean.

If I find a person to be ethically compromised, I might play tricks on this person to get desired results. But most of the time I like to help people and see them thrive. I might be a bit of a control nut but overall have good intentions. 

Can anyone else relate?

column2: What is the ENFJ World like?
column3:
Hey! I am genuinely curious of how Fe manifest in daily life and on the long term. I have a poor grasp of cognitive functions, and I think I learn better through actual examples rather than a website just telling me how it manifests. 

SOOOOOOOO...IN SIMPLE TERMS>...What is the inner world of the ENFJ? Struggles? Strengths? How is life as an Fe dom' ENFJ?

column2: Signs an ENFJ man likes you?
column3:
Hello all! I was wondering if someone could give me an idea as to what an ENFJ man might do if they liked you? Some background:

A guy started working at my work about a month and a half ago, and instantly I hated him. I guess I was just being jealous and competitive, as he walked right in and earned the appreciation that I?ôd been busting my guts for for over six months, to no avail. But upon working on a one to one basis with him, I realised just how lovely he was. He was always friendly with me, telling me to take deep breaths when I got stressed out, just being the stereotypical healthy ENFJ. He gets along with literally everyone at my work, because he?ôs so lovely to everyone. I didn?ôt mean to develop feelings for him, but I did. 

A bunch of girls I work with have mentioned that they think he might have a thing for me. He?ôs extremely playful with me: tickling my neck and sides because he knows I?ôm ticklish, calling me by a petname, throwing tomatoes at me (we work in a food prep area), jokingly trying to trip me up and other things to try and make me laugh. Whenever he greets me he hugs me, and on one occasion I was having a bit of a panic attack serving customers and he dropped everything to help me, knowing that this would inevitably make his job harder. One time he found out I was walking home and said ?úno you?ôre not - come on, I?ôm driving you home?? We?ôve even got to the point where we trust each other enough to talk about very personal things to us. I?ôve been through some very bad things and he assured me that good would come of them, and told me he was always there for me should I need him. I even heard from a friend that someone was being horrible about me and he stuck up for me, and one time she said to him ?úI?ôm happy to see her [me] happy,??to which he responded with ?úI?ôm happy to see her always?? I can?ôt work out if this behaviour is flirty or friendly especially as ENFJs have a tendency to blur the lines. I?ôd love to hear your thoughts about his behaviour and maybe give me ideas as to what you guys do when you?ôre interested in a person! Thank you!

So...I have been researching, over and over, like a mad person, and trying to figure out if I am ENFJ or INFJ...Maybe to an unhealthy degree....
Anyway, I was wondering if we can, together, cross examine the functions as they behave in both types. For example, ENFJs are said to exercise during moments of stress. I *hate* exercising unless it's useful (martial arts makes sense to me as a form of workout; running in a treadmill reminds me of hamsters, and I don't see the fun in it). With that said, I *need* some sort of exercise to feel happy, whether it's martial arts, running, walking...But I need it to be a natural thing, not forced....am I making any sense? 
When I am really down in the dumps, I usually think that I am not loved or needed and am a burden on people- the last thing I will think of is exercise.....I'll think of spending the day by myself so I don't bother anyone.

So what kind of Se is that??????Is it in the 3rd or 4th place?

My Ni and Fe are 50-50, and so I don't know which one I developed first. What does Ni look like as auxiliary, and what does it look like as dominant???? What about Fe??????

Is anyone stuck in the same situation, where they are really not sure if they are INFJ or ENFJ????
It's not like there's a free test for this.....
Thanks in advance...

column2: What MBTI Type Would You Want Your Child To Be?
column3:
What MBTI type would you want your children to be if you have some or want some in the future? I stole this from the INFP forum but I think It would be nice to hear from my fellow ENFJs.

Mine would be: 

1.(ISFx) 
2.(xNFx) 

but I'm sure yours is probably different

Hi all!

I met two ENFJs yesterday on the 3D game Second Life.  Before this, I was not aware of anyone I know being ENFJ.

The first chat I had with each of them were very stimulating and "alive", much more so than usual.  So I got a great first impression of your type.  Today I had another (brief) chat, which was initiated by myself (in contrast to the first two), and it was mediocre and afflicted with boring silences.

I definitely take a lot of responsibility for the disappointing quality of today's chat, as I am apathetic due to residual depression.  It makes me feel empty of thoughts and feelings, and so I find scarcely anything to say, which does a lot to ruin my chatting pleasure.  I can barely make small talk.  However, this was not at all any kind of prominent problem in the first two ("good") chats, so I'm looking for factors beyond myself.

So I was wondering if it is common for ENFJs to be in chatty vs. unchatty moods.  I realise all types can have a bad day, but it did not sound like she was down.

If anyone would like to chat with me, to get an idea of what I'm talking about, just drop me a line in PM and we'll figure out a way.

I'm an xxNP; that part is beyond debate, but I've tested as all 4 NP types, most recently ENFP.  If I had to choose one, I'm leaning to ENTP when I'm feeling better (which makes me more extraverted), or INTP when I'm feeling worse.

Cheers,
Albert.

I think neediness is in every person, but I want to deal with the neediness of each gender separately. Males have a certain needy stereotype, which I want to explore with you all.

1. I want to agree on what neediness is, through sharing examples. 

2. I want to think about what a needy person's daily routine might be, to see what conditions could contribute to neediness growing within us.

3. I want to think of ways to drain neediness away. Is it as simple as getting laid? Male neediness isn't merely physical (masturbation doesn't solve a broken heart, for example), it has emotional components too. How do you drain your stock of neediness?

Personally, I think neediness drips in from the subconscious, perpetually like hunger or thirst, and it's either satisfied or not by your daily routine. I think sometimes you may not know or believe that you're acting needy when you are. And I think if you have a lot of neediness built up, then when you speak it'll show itself and disappoint everyone, to your dismay. So my initial thought is that it's good to dissolve it when it accumulates, and also pursue routines that'd keep it at a comfortable level.

That being said, I want to distinguish neediness from expressing desire for someone or something. If you have a passionate crush on some INFP, you may express desire for them without necessarily being needy. But if you irritate them with constant begging, and by ignoring their subtle rejections, then you're clearly acting on needy impulses. It's inside of us.

Have you been needy before? Are any guys in your life particularly needy? What are some examples of neediness?

I find that the more mature I get the more I like to define things percisely. Like ideas, feelings, etc. Like I wanna experience them (Ni->Se) and then analysis it logically. Break it down. Is this just mbti placebo (lol) or can you relate to it? It basically seems like a full experience of the ENFJ-stack:
1. Everybodys feelings
2. My concept, ideas, peeceptions
3. Actually experience, do or whatever
4. Break it down percisely and internally logical (in a more detached, non-judgmental, non-controlling (so more P-ish instead of J-ish basically) way)


Anyone get me? Lol

Hey everyone.

I came across this forum after experiencing a really close connection with a fellow ENFJ, and it's made me realise how much I'd love to come across similar people. Would be super happy to chat and make new friends (whether you're a ENFJ too or if you fancy chatting to one yourself).

I'm 29 (30 in just over a week - eek...) and live in England, I'm chronically unwell and have been for a number of years and find I really enjoy close/deep connections. I'm pretty kind and caring and love to be there for others, I think I'm quite a true ENFJ.

I'll keep it short and sweet, but if anyone is up for a chat I'd be happy to receive your message!

As a side note, how do I add an avatar to my account? Maybe I'm just being incredibly stupid but I can't see it on the profile settings bit. TIA

Becca

column2: Seeking Beautiful ENFJ Souls to help with complex matter. Join today!
column3:
Hey all to my favourite personality type.

I've been lurking around PerC and have always been impressed by how useful this community is. God bless you all.

This is the first time I've been reaching out online to some assistance on a very complicated matter. 

Reaching out is a big step for me since I am, typical INFJ, extremely private and misunderstood. 

I would like a few people, 3 maximum, to PM and share what has happened regarding a complex situation with another whom I love unconditionally. 

Please note this will be a LONG and complex read. There is no TLDR. It WILL be "weird".

If you are up for some... Interesting stuff and want to help, please help me. 

This is UK based - being from UK may help in understanding cultural barriers potentially but of course no strict requirement. 

No rush in discussing either - maybe 1 PM every other day or so, whatever suits you. I work long hours, so understand you may be busy too. 

A massive thank you to anyone who has read this. Once I have enough volunteers, I will put another message on this thread. 

God bless you all ??

column2: Does this ENFJ girl like me?
column3:
She?ôs an ENFJ, so obviously very friendly to everyone and hard to read thoroughly. I was wondering if you guys had any opinion on whether she likes me or not. We?ôre both in high school. 

- We flirt all the time although she?ôs the natural flirting type

- I?ôm the one she mostly flirts with; our verbal flirting game is superb. However, with others she doesn?ôt verbally flirt with them as much and instead touches them on the arm or shoulder. The only touches I get are high fives ?? which I haven?ôt seen her give to anyone else

- Whenever someone is talking to us when we?ôre in a group, she always looks at me to see my reaction

- At lunch I?ôm always the first person she talks to and she?ôs always excited to see me, perhaps more so than others

- She teases me and has a teasing nickname for me

- When I was going away on a trip, according to friends she was looking at me the entire time in the class before I left

Can?ôt tell if she likes me or just enjoys my company ??

column2: Cognitive Functions + Neurology = How ENFJ brains work
column3:
I've been a member of these forums for a while now and one thing I've noticed about those new to MBTI is that as soon as they don't understand the theory they attempt to dismiss it as "pop psychology" with no basis in reality and just a bunch of abstract mumbojumbo...well...apparently with advancements in technology we are able to see that Jung's theory of cognitive functions is actually supported via EEGs. Basically an individual's "cognitive processes" can be observed and turns out certain parts of the brain are more active for people who share an MBTI type. For those of you interested in learning more I highly suggest getting the book (https://smile.amazon.com/Neuroscien...F8&qid=1543607555&sr=8-1&keywords=dario+nardi) I doubt you will be disappointed.

Since I discovered Micheal Pierce's channel because someone posted his ENFJ video on the ENFJ forums I will be passing it forward to give our subforums a much needed break from the usual "relationship drama" and something about cognitive functions. Most youtube videos about MBTI suck and because the person making the video understands little about the theory and spreads misinformation. I made the mistake of skipping this video when I seen it in my recommendations awhile back and rediscovered it. He's talking about the content form the book above and uses video games tog get his points across. I watched all his videos about the functions and it gets my seal of approval. The guy knows what he is talking about and not just pulling information from his ass.  Would love to hear what you guys think about the video.  

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-mU9y7f9-ik

column2: Which personality types (mbti) have you dated?
column3:
Hi ENFJs (or any NFs or types that dated NFs),

What personality types have you dated/married, where it has been good relationship for you? What were the pros and cons, and what did you do to strengthen the relationship? Any relationships that were more challenging and it didn't last? You can expand how you want.

column2: ENFJs and the Importance of Religion in Your Lives.
column3:
Hello all you wonderful ENFJs!

So going by the few ENFJs I have met and watched on Youtube, 4/5 are deeply religious. The fifth one might also be religious, I just haven't watched the vlog where she admits to practicing a religion yet. I can see how religion can be very attractive to ENFJs and this made me curious about several things I would like to discuss with the community.

1. Are you religious?
2. Were you raised to follow a religion or did you adopt a religion of your own free will? Did you change your religion to a different one? Did someone introduce you to a religion?
3. What religion are you practicing?
4. If you are religious, what is it about the religion that you like as an ENFJ? Is it the doctrine? Or the sense of community? Both? Or something else? Please elaborate.  
5. What does religion mean to you; how important is religion in your life as an ENFJ?
6. Which of your functions does religion satisfy and in what way?
7. How important is it for your SO to be religious? Would you raise your children to follow the same religion or let them choose for themselves?

A little about myself: I myself am not practicing a religion. I don't frown upon it, I am knowledgeable of many religions and am respectful of all but certainly I don't know about all religions. I find religion very interesting and I may become religious in the future. I am an ENFP and this type has a tendency to shy away from commitment. I'm not saying that I cannot commit to something, I would just prefer not to in order to keep more options available to me. 

I also want to say thank you to everyone who has taken the time to read and/or participate in this thread. The more questions you can answer would be greatly appreciated but not mandatory.

column2: How good are ENFJs with communication?
column3:
Hi everybody INFP here who just wants to understand his ENFJ friend a little better and wants to relieve his insecurities a bit. How good are you guys with communication? Are you consistent? Me and my friend (who's a girl) have been LD friends for years now but she recently started her first year of uni. Up until when she entered uni, we were having conversations frequently. The longest we'd ever gone without exchanging a text over the last 3 years was a week. Nowadays the few times we do text, the conversation is rather short and ends abruptly because she just stops answering. I'm already in my 2nd year of college, so I understand her being too busy with her new lifestyle to text me as frquently as she used to, but I still get insecure about her just forgetting about me, losing interesting in keeping up with me, and then eventually replacing me with some other friends who actually live in her country. I also try my best to text at least once a week just to check in on her, but I feel like I'm being overbearing, so I'm considering stopping and letting her have some space. And I'll repeat that I know she just got into university less than 2 months ago, but I can't help feeling neglected in spite of that, as selfish as that sounds. But I'm dealing with it the best I can, and I wou;;dn't want to mentally burden her by telling her any of this because I know that would make her feel like shit. Our friendship means too much to me.

But I'll add that she's aware that she hasn't been great at getting back to me. Every time she has gotten back to me, she has been apologetic for not being better at it. And I definitely appriciate it.

I know that what I'm worried about is silly and I should probably stop being so insecure about my relationship with somebody a whole ocean away, but again, I can't help it.

But are a lot of ENFJs like this? Do you get so busy you end up neglecting your friends? Should I continue checking in on her weekly/bi-weekly or is that an annoyingly bad idea?

column3: Is there any things you guys do in particular when a specific somebody means a lot to you? (At least, more than the average joe)

column2: INTJ in need of help with my ENFJ
column3:
I was hoping to get some thoughts and advice on how to help my ENFJ girlfriend through a particularly rough patch in her life. For context, I'm an INTJ female although I think that having lived for almost four decades and being a mother has taught me to be more sensitive, empathetic INTJ. My gf and I have been together for a year and a half now, lived together since the beginning of the year. We are very happy together and are committed to one another but she has other factors that are causing her a great deal of stress. Lately she has felt like running away and told my earlier today that she is seriously considering going to stay with her mom (states away from where we currently live) for a few months to try and sort through some of her thoughts. Without giving all the complicated details, she is feeling very stuck and controlled by an outside element. She needs to give that situation time to play out before she can take back some control on that front. I've reassured her that if she needs some time that I'll support her and it doesn't change anything for me. At this point I am trying to make sure she's feeling as little pressure coming from me as possible. 

My questions are is the urge to run common with ENFJs, and if so, what helps you when you feel this way? Am I right in my approach or could me giving her space be viewed as not fighting for her? Any ENFJ specific de-stressing tips or thoughts on ways to help her deal with her stress would be greatly appreciated. I know that in the past I have gotten myself all messed up trying to feel when I should be thinking and it seems that she is relying to heavily on thinking right now. Are there ways that I can help her in this area?

Any thoughts or perspectives are greatly appreciated!

Good morning,

I'm posting on here in the hope that I'll invite some enlightening insight into an ongoing issue my ENFJ partner is experiencing regarding personal confrontation.

She's the very epitome of an ENFJ, and an artist - a good one too, I love her work. She has an ongoing mimic of sorts, however, who seems unable to resist leeching off her ideas and effectively copying them at every given opportunity (tis the era of social media, this annoying shit just happens sadly). This has been a problem for some years now, unchanging, and it's something that really troubles her for a number of reasons I'll save for if anybody wants to better inform any advice they might have. Now, I sympathise for her, I really do; social media has very little bearing on my own life, and I don't care for it in the slightest, but it doesn't mean I don't appreciate why these distanced acts of creative theft are very frustrating for her. Regardless, I can't help but take issue with the fact that she simply refuses to address the matter directly.

She knows the 'thief' personally, has done for years (though they aren't friends and don't have any direct contact), and this problem really isn't going away. I don't care for confrontation myself, at all, but I feel I know when to draw the line, take a deep breath and have it out with somebody - diplomatically of course - and unfortunately, the more this issue comes up, the less I'm able to align my feelings with my partner's and simply comfort her, because at this late stage something direct really needs to be done. Put very simply, her mimic needs to fuck off. The problem is, my partner simply will not have it - she resists any and all suggestions to speak to her thief directly, and becomes rather irritated with me quite quickly for not just looking after her hurt feelings and for focusing on how the matter could actually be practically resolved. I'm well aware that practical advice is not always the best port of call for matters of emotions, but this has simply gone on long enough, and she really needs to go about this ongoing situation in a different way or it will just continue to upset her and render me an unwanted practical advisor.

Any thoughts on the matter would be most appreciated. I would very much like to help my partner out of this frustrating situation of hers.

https://www.5lovelanguages.com/profile/
11	Physical Touch
8	Quality Time
7	Words of Affirmation
4	Acts of Service
0	Receiving Gifts

What are your Love Language hierarchies? Surprisingly, as an INTJ, touch was high on mine (Se?).

column2: Loneliness and lack of confidence as a child
column3:
This is something I have been thinking about for a couple of years, so it might be the time to get some other perspectives.

I'm obviously an ENFJ and Enneagram 9w1. The thing is, as a child, say from 6 years to like 22, I was extremely unsure of myself. I have so many memories where I are in tune with how others are feeling, and put them ahead of myself.

I never really stood up for myself against bullies, even though I wasn't really afraid of getting hurt. I have a brother 8 years older than me and we used to fight a lot, and it made me used to getting hurt during a fight haha. Still, with kids my own age, I was afraid when they tried to dominate me. I have no idea why.

I remember my father dropping me off at karate for the first time and I was so unsure of myself and scared (again not sure of what I was scared of). Never did karate again. And it wasn't the physicality of it all, but more like I couldn't deal with everyones expectations on me. Like I didn't know how to act.

I was even scared of going into the ocean, which is so weird as I'm heavy into surfing now and not scared at all haha. As a result of being so scared of shit, I never did sports (except swimming which I excelled at) and never really tried to be friends with the sporty kids as I felt intimidated by them (I never stood up for myself). This resulted in me being friends with kids that didn't intimidate me but who I never really connected with either. It's like I understood and identified with the sporty kids but they never accepted me because I didn't do sports with them. So I felt like an outsider. I knew where I belonged but still didn't belong.

My own friends, even though I liked them, I was never like them. In highschool I had 3 seperate friend groups, all different from each other, but all of them NOT into sports. And then in my last year I succeeded in being accepted by a sporty group of friends, and I felt at home like never before.

Still, I don't understand why I was so unsure of myself as a kid. It really created a lot of problems and other issues for me later in life, loneliness being one of them.

Today I have a lot of friends who are the kind of sport people I always craved, but I still have such a huge gap in my own sport experience that I still can't identify fully with them. I can only do single athlete sport but when it comes to team games, I'm useless. It also eats me up that I want to be like them, could have been like them, but missed the train due to my own fear of who knows what as a child. The result is extreme loneliness even though I am constantly with people.

I realised this tonight again when I told my best friend, that I have to sort my life out and need his advice. He is an ESTP so I didn't really expect a solid reply.

His answer though blew me away. He said we should go eat something and then we can talk and he will help me. It was then that I realised i've never fucking ever felt that anybody really cared about me. It's like I play a role 99% of the time and even though I have lots of friends and they are good people, we are not on the same level except for this friend.. and maybe one other friend. Could I really have been craving this kind of connection with people my whole life?

My parents, although good people, never connected with me. Our emotional bond is kind of like the bond you have with your maths teacher, but you have seen them in their underwear lol. Jokes aside, they care but we don't connect.

So does anybody have anything to add to this? I'm not always sure if I am on the right track in sorting myself out. I struggle with depression, anxiety and contemplating suicide on and off for the last 10 years. I am planning on getting proffessional help, but that's not an option right now and I'm not really keen on talking with a stranger face to face with this stuff.

Just to add cause it might sound absolutely stupid to care so much about sport, but where I live, sport is ingrained into our culture and it might have messed me up a little in my forming years.

I did get out of my "afraid of fucking everything (are we allowed to swear on the forum?) mindset, when I made a SPORTY friend who I idealised greatly. I then went to transform my whole life, started working out, made friends, started surfing, MMA and even started swimming again. I outgrew so much of my fears, l almost got shot a couple of years back haha and today I'm another person, except I can't do the sports I missed out as a child even though 90% of our male population can.

So I still kinda feel like an outsider, except I've upgraded to include depression, anxiety and suicide. It's really starting to screw me up but I can't seem to get to the root cause.

Just to add, our religion is RUGBY. I don't really care but I missed out on a lot of good memories for being to afraid of.. I still don't know.

It resulted in me feeling isolated. So my question is this. What the hell was wrong with me as a child? Why was I so scared? Why didn't I dominate the other kids? Why was I so out of touch with my own strenghts? Why was I always running away?

My life is really screwed up because of how I reacted as a kid. I might have exaggerated a bit on how many friends I have, as I don't see most of them regularly. Even today, I'm still unsure of myself in social situations, don't know why. It's like I don't let myself count, but not due to self-esteem cause I like myself haha. I'm just not focussed on myself when speaking with people.. but it's automated so don't know how to stop it.

column2: ENFJ guy used to message every day... we had a first date... then he disappeared?
column3:
Long story short, I had an amazing first date with an ENFJ guy I met online. In the week leading up to the date, he was messaging me 2 or 3x a day... the date itself was just wonderful, great conversations, and towards the end of it he  leaned in to say "so... may I call again?" with a very intent look in his eyes, to which I responded "that would be great!!" 

Afterwards, he walked me to my car, and then turned to leave - he didn't try to hug me - is that unusual for ENFJ's, if he liked me?  The next morning, I awoke with fear that I had forgotten to thank him for the date (he paid, and drove a good distance to where I live). So I sent him a quick message, apologizing that I may have forgotten, and said I had such a great time. He responded, within minutes, to say "oh no worries, you were great! I had a great time, too!" with two smiley faces... so I felt better... and waited to hear from him again. Since then, radio silence.  Two full days... whereas he was messaging every day, prior to the date.

What could this mean?? Do ENFJs ever disappear after a date? Or is this a sign he lost interest for good?

I met her 3 years ago I she became my friend. She was fine at first, but now she is so annoying. I know she's ENFJ - A  I know - not every ENFJ is the same. But I only want to know is it normal for ENFJ or she is just "exceptional":
1. She thinks life without 8372983978 friends is boring and if I don't have lots of friend I'm worse. I remember when I had an argument with her and she told me "What do you know about friendship? You have only a few friends" I don't have to have 98732987243 friends to know what friendship is and in my view my friendships are deeper than her, because she thinks if she know someone for for example 8 months she can trust him. And I need more time to trust someone.
2. She is always being a smart aleck, even when she isn't right. I remember a situation, when she was smarting off before a test and when the teacher gave the tests us back - she got 3 (or D). 
3. She is illogical. Her statements aren't based on facts, just on "because I think so" For example:
M - me 
S - she
S: He's very calm.
M: Why do you think that? You don't know him well.
S: Because he goes to bed at 10 o'clock and wakes up at 6 o'clock. 
WTF?

What can I do with her? Her behaviour is pissing me off.

column3:
