column2: ENTP (me) starting to Fall To An ENFJ girl with Gay Friend Giving Me Mixed Signals
column3:
Context: We are workmates (I know, don't shit where you eat but I am willing to take some risk just so because I know I can get away with it).

Basically, our team is composed of 5 men (3 of them are married, me and another guy are single). Last January, this girl came from a different project together with her gay workmate (they are in the same project before).

To add substance, the ENPJ girl is an HB7 and her gay friend is an HB4. Like 5'4, around 200 pounds, dark skin, but is very kind and agrees to whatever she says and pleases. The gay guy does not get mad, angry, etc. You can literally make a personal joke about him and he will just take it.

Girl's story: She had her heart broken by a guy more than a year ago. I saw her ex's picture (he is heterosexual). She also said this breakup has no closure and she just want to know why they broke up. I was able to know this information since my married co-workers asked her and I am just listening while she is revealing this -- this was during valentine's day (1 week before her birthday). This is when I concluded that she is into real men, not gays. But am I wrong?

Girl and her gay friend: They ride the same uber cab, she grabs the gay's arm and puts it on her breast as they walk. They watch movies together, they eat together at fast food chains, they talk about everything. I mean, if no one said that guy is **** I would definitely think they are BF/GF. But it does not add up because the guy is gay, and she is at least 3 levels above him in terms of appearance. The guy is also not rich or anything. Like I mentioned, the gay person is very kind.

Girl's personality: Down to earth, friendly creature with a very kind smile and she has a big heart. She also doesn't do party-party, prefers to stay inside a condo unit when work is done and she lives in a condo with some of her roomies (all female).

Girl and interaction with me: So initially, we don't really begin to talk much. I am very talkative (entp) but it took a while, at least a month, before she starts talking to me comfortably. During this time, there are moments where she wants to know more personal things about me but I heard her asking my married co-workmate to know where I live/stay, instead of directly asking this to me.

There was also a moment when one of my married co-worker said something like "You know [jenny] asked something about you".. and jenny was like "don't tell him, don't hell him" and her body language got really animated like a little girl. Later on, I found out from my co-worker that she asked "if I am already married" --- perhaps, she got that impression because I am very well-dressed and formal at work.

This girl has a very cheerful personality, her eyes light up when she starts to talk to me, she laughs at any simple joke I make. Now, if I compare this to my other workmates even to the other single guy, I believe she laughs even harder when she is with me. The only person where she shows that kind of personality is when she is with the gay guy.

I also noticed that when it's only the two of us in the shift. Or, if we're just the two people alone in the office. She starts to visit me at my cubicle and we can talk for several hours. It feels relaxing to talk to her. During this instance, she asked a lot of things about me. But more than that, she shared something and she was asking almost begging not to tell it to anyone (it's work related). And I say yes, you can trust me. And yes, she told it to me.

When we talk personally, our chairs are like less than a foot away from one another. She likes to cross legs and all her body language are positive directing to me. She also sometimes lick her lips (a few times, could be accidental).

She is like kinda hesitant to touch me. I feel like she wants to, because there's an instance when I was fixing a problem and I made a funny error and she was like going to touch me, but instead went for my chair and starts shaking it.

This girl also sometimes say things to me like "I heard that woman at the other floor is your crush". Sometimes, she even say things like "Hey, that girl on the other cubicle is only 22 years old" then say "yiheeee" with a big grin. Sometimes, she calls me "dude" in front of my co-workers.

There was a time our female manager tried to tease me and her, but I frowned and shrug it off. I believe it's one of the reasons why she does not want to touch me. I still do not know. I am perplexed.

When I am at work and in hyperfocus mode and she asked me something and I was like giving her unemotional logical questions why she did this and that, she started to run like a few feet away from me like a little girl then asked our female manager of the same question. I am like whaat?

She is the only person who can detect when I am down eventhough I am good at hiding my feelings. Then she will ask things like "what's wrong, are you alright?". Then when I reveal what's causing it, she will make sure that I will feel good later on.

Today's events: Usual work with her gay friend and while we are on our workstation she mentioned words to her friend like "my parents are at my condo, you should come with me so it will be like "meet the parents", "then let's go to the church after", she also said "what lipstick should I wear, maybe I should wear black [giggled a lot]".

The crazy thing is that, she calls the gay as "girl". Like for example, "you can do it girl", "let's go girl!", "hey girl" -- numerous times.

Now, this is driving me really nuts. I mean, you treat this gay guy like your boyfriend/husband already but you call that person a "girl". And no, they are not in a relationship at all. That I can guarantee with her previous workmates.

About me

I'm her superior, HB8, 178CM - 160 pounds, 6% body fat. That's already considered a hunk for an asian guy living in an asian country. I am the richest guy on our team, I have a successful business, has high confidence, will not hesitate to do cold approaches to a woman that I find physically attractive.

It's funny because when I was inside a restaurant and I was walking in a suit, ENPJ girl said "you're handsome" in a kidding way. She also said it again, a week later when she saw my phone's wallpaper with me doing selfie on a beach -- she said "wow, you are so handsome" but this time, it was a shy type statement just before she walks away. But yes, I did hear her say it.

Questions

1) This is driving me crazy. As an ENTP, it's important for me to create a logical structure of a person first before I dive. For this one, a lot of of the puzzle pieces are missing or seem to be incongruent. For example, a girl who is an HB7 staying with an HB4 gay guy who is very kind, dark and fatty but she acts as if they are BF/GF wherein in her previous relationship, that she cannot get over with, her guy is a real man -- not gay. I do not get this. Why?

2) This girl and the gay act as if they are lovers/couples already but she call the gay guy as "girl". Why?

3) Do you think this girl and her gay friend are in a romantic/bf/gf type of relationship?

4) Why is she like that? It does not make any sense.

5) Will she be able to accept me, if I tried to date her? It's like I value personality more than anything and I can see we can fit. But I just want to know if she has already decided with the gay guy or not.

-- Help please.

My little brother is an ENFJ and oddly enough, and it seems like he works only on inspiration.  He's quite a procrastinator for a J which I find puzzling (so maybe he is more P?).  In any event, he does this thing where he gets so inspired to do something and gets behind an idea completely - furthermore, he's so influential that everyone around him gets behind him and his idea - and then for whatever reason, he simply changes his mind.  It drives us all nuts!

For example, he is trying to figure out what to do after high school.  He sort of tried the college thing and that didn't work out, so now he's thinking he might try to go to another college or move out of the country or something.  Everyone rallies around him and starts to fill out applications for him (because he is completely on-board and asks for our help), but then (often the very next day) he backs off and says, "Oh, no, nevermind."   Well, then he misses deadlines and gets upset (has regret)!

It seems to be becoming a sort of boy who cried wolf situation here.  It is hard to believe him when he says he wants to do such and such and will we help him.  At the same time, we WANT to help him, and I know he struggles with stuff like filling out applications and the boring things that I can whip through -- at the same time, I don't really want to whip through 20 applications only for him to change his mind YET AGAIN.

Any suggestions or ideas on what might be going on here?  

My ISTP husband says to make him fill everything out himself.  I get this point - if he wants to do it enough, he will. I mean, in theory.  But, the thing is, my bro does seem to need a lot of help with stuff and gets kind of down on himself when he is unable to do it (i.e. "I am such a loser - I can't even fill out an application on time.").  And honestly, I think if there were not any work to set it up, and he could just get on a plane or head off to college without all the nonsense paperwork, that he'd go.  He just doesn't want to do the work that will get him there because he's not certain that he wants to go, but then rethinks it and is like... man, I wish I had done it.  AHHH.

I think one of my friends is ENFJ, I am just not 100% sure because some of his behavior doesn't fit in the ENFJ stereotype.

First of all he is very charismatic, the most charismatic person I know. He does everything very slowly and is very calm. He is also a great listener, a person who gains your trust very easily. I am pretty sure he has Ni as one of his dominant functions.
That all seems to make him an ENFJ.

But he is really really ignorant. He is a good listener on the one hand but doesn't really feel the need to help anyone who is in need. He just help when someone is really really in need. I know from all ESFJs I know that they care before you even ended the sentence. That's definitely not him. He is also not really sensitive, he knows good what others are feeling but doesn't really "let it touch" him, how he calls it. 
He is also very messy and did nothing for the last three years. I think he is 21 now, cancelled school at age 19 and is doing nothing since then.
Does this still fit an ENFJ?

My INFJ friend has a way stronger Fe I think, or at least a Fe which has some other features. He is constantly aware of not hurting anyone while my ENFJ friend seems to be a lot cooler with that. It seems more like he exactly knows how to behave to make you feel good while not seeming overcaring.

What do you think?

Is this ENFJ really into me?

Hello ENFJs! I would like to know if my relationship with an ENFJ male seem to be developing positively.

First off, I met him like two weeks ago in a party. He was drunk. He wanted to kiss me but I wasn't into kissing strangers at THAT moment (later you'll discover why I say this).
I went away with my friend to dance (this friend is the one who introduced him to me).

The next day I received a message from him. He asked my number to my friend. His first message was "A beautiful girl owes me a kiss...", I was like "Keep dreaming." and the conversation went on and on...

He proposed me to hang out to the cinema, he was so funny. Then another day we went to the beach and well this day we kissed (first time kissing a "stranger"). At this point I thought I had screwed it up cause I think he likes challenges and I let him kiss me. So the next day we hanged out I didn't let him, although he stole me one kiss. After that stolen kiss we promised we wouldn't kiss again that day (I don't want to go that quickly, we're just "friends" and we're getting to know each other, too soon for so much kiss). Again I fell due to his enchantment, we were playing a board game and he bet a kiss. I lose. However this time I had to be the one giving the kiss. But we bet before that if I kissed him that day we would have a dinner. I wanted that dinner. So I kissed him and I broke my promise. Great... 

What do you think? He is really interested or just playing with me? He's 21 and I'm 19. He said he didn't want to define our relationship as it's soon. But I'm not used to have this affections with friends. I'm confused about his intentions... He likes to give me kisses in the forehead  as he knows I won't hit him for that. But, indeed, those kisses have more effect on me than any other type of kiss, so pure and true.

I saw a conversation he had with my friend and he said I am a good girl (I'm not sure if that is good as others can interpret goodness as "naive" o "dumb").

I am not the best at all at typing people. I can pick between introvert and extrovert and that about all. :dry: But I want to spot ENFJ's in particular because I think that one of them would be my perfect match. Being an INTJ I done my research on them, but still cant really know how to find them. But if and when I do find them I will make an effort to talk to them and get to know them. Because I feel something but cant really describe it :blushed:. Also, do I even have a chance with one? On everything that i read it says that they don't make good matches for an  INTJ, if I do have a chance with one what does an ENFJ look for in a partner what can I do to make them feel good and happy. I am a girl if you didn't know that so try to make suggestions for me off of that. I hope I don't get shoot down for posting this on your guys forums.

I've come to the conclusion as of late that my type isn't generally accepted and understood in large part because of the fact that I am a female. ENFJ males are very rare, and therefore their strength and sensitive disposition gives them an edge up in leadership roles.

However, I feel as though, partially because I'm a woman, my opinionated nature, leadership abilities, and even general intelligence are overlooked. 

As an ENFJ, I have developed clear and succinct opinions on many issues that I feel are overlooked because of my gender. I'm not sure if it's because many men (and women!) hold onto old-fashioned ideas about gender-placing a male in a more dominant role. It definitely seems more comfortable and accepted to many people.

I remember a thread way back when where some individuals were talking about what types would work best with ENFJs. Someone suggested that every NF type worked well with an ENFJ male, but not an ENFJ female. 

In fact, that person suggested that INFJ may be the only "plausible" option for me.

I understand where this is coming from, but that doesn't mean I'm perfectly okay with it.

ENFJ ladies, have you ever struggled with your femininity as a strong, leading personality type? How does the world interact with you/ how has it affected your relationships?

I'm interested in the opinion of other ENFJ females, but anyone of any type (male or female) is encouraged to post.

:]

Hello beautiful creatures,
My story begins upon meeting an ESFJ a little while ago, we became good friends, albeit with little to no chemistry. However, I did notice him paying close attention to what is considered "normal" by our general society, and noticing how people would view his actions. That definitely didn't sit right with me, as a rebel to all that is normal, but I played it off my mind like a champ. Not until he commented on my recetly-acquired highlights with "what would people think?"
My question is this:
"Do ENFJs let other people influence their actions?/Do they base their actions on what is socially acceptable by many?"

Thanks in advance,
hope someone made you crack up today:wink:

column2: ENFJ waterworks - how easily do you cry?
column3:
My ENFJ dad cries openly and easily from joy, or in empathy with others who are deeply moved. He cries readily but quietly in grief. In all those circumstances, he's quite at peace with crying - totally unembarrassed. However, I would say that he cries neither often nor very gracefully in confrontations. 

My ENFJ childhood best-friend cries very easily over pretty much everything, and she haaaates it. 

I cry easily enough at movies, shows, commercials - but it makes me maaaaad, because I think that's dumb, so I try to hide it and really rather don't want it mentioned: if you do point it out, I will biff you with a cushion. I'm pretty steely in confrontations - I hate crying because it makes me inarticulate, and distracts from the issue at hand. I've never cried from joy, per se, but I have done so as a reaction to beauty, which is similar. I'm never particularly comfortable with doing it, though, and kinda feel like I ought to be?

So, do you cry much? When and how? Have you intentionally tried to develop yourself in this area?

The title says is it all. It seems obvious on paper but I don't fully understand what's the difference when it comes to how that applies in someone's life. Aren't both types supposed to be a people's type? I know the difference is in how they process things, but most ENFJ I know have a good Se and ngl I don't fully understand the difference between Se and Si yet to begin with. Some insights would be helpful.

Edit: What does an ENFJ do that an ESFJ would never do and vice versa?

column2: Unhealthy ENFJ - I hate my personality, How do I change it?
column3:
I am a super unhealthy ENFJ post breakup right now. I feel hurt, scarred, betrayed, used, disgusted at myself and how human beings can be so selfish, angry, upset.

I blame myself for being naive and feeling so much. I hate it that my Fe is 80% and I really just want to be someone who doesn't care about anyone at all. (Maybe like a ISTP, as they are logical, thinkers and only care about themselves most of the time).

Any ideas /resources how I can develop my Ti to overshadow my Fe? I think it is not possible to completely change into another personality? I would definitely like to change to a ISTP, for the fact that it seems like my ISTP ex could hurt me like it's not a biggie/ I deserve to be hurt like that.
